g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
of driver variables with more or less deforestation
The global forest area in 2020 is estimated at 4.1 billion ha, representing 31% of the total land area
. Most forests are situated in the tropics (45%), followed by boreal (27%), temp
and subtropical (11%) domains. Considering regional distribution of global forest area, Europe and the
Russian Federation accounts for 25%, followed by South America (21%), North and Central America
(5%). However, a significant share (54%) of the world’s
the Russian Federation, Brazil, Canada, the
. Forest loss rates differ among regions though the global trend
is towards a net forest loss
. The global forest area declined by about 178 Mha in the 30 years from 1990 to
. The rate of net forest loss
has decreased since 1990, a result of reduced deforestation
in some countries and forest gains in others. The annual net loss of forest area declined from 7.8 Mha
. The rate of decline in net forest loss during the last decade was
due mainly to an increase in the rate of forest gain (i.e. afforestation and the natural expansion of
the area of the more open, other wooded land is also of significant importance, with almost 1
he area of other wooded land decreased by 30.6
in monitoring the area of other wooded land, largely associated with difficulties in measuring tree
canopy cover in the range of 5
, has also experienced a significant decline
